The red herring seems to be the requirement:

> It should work using on Tor (TCP only, maybe UDP on clearnet)

Can we generalize this requirement?  What are the requirement for Tor?  Anonymity?  Privacy?  So, how can you use DHT in a way that preserves these basic requirements, while not necessarily using Tor and not impeding the ability to use Tor for the rest of ZeroNet's functions?  

So, when I look at [OpenDHT](https://github.com/savoirfairelinux/opendht), I wonder to what extent this capability helps meet these core requirements:

> Public key cryptography layer providing optional data signature and encryption (using GnuTLS)

Could roll this into a higher level requirement for centralized configuration, or more generally, a hash table where the keys are delimited text, and the values are ZN objects (for images) or text (username, etc,...).  

E.g., key: "/users/{user id}/profile/avatar", value: "{znId}"

The tough part is how to distribute it.  As this could grow to a very big size as it becomes a DB for anything.  

Obviously, this is distributed hash table (DHT).  I don't know enough about DHTs being used in P2P to know if they complete this requirement in a way where it fits this use with ZeroNet.  If they are a fit, and DHT is currently a feature request, then this issue could become dependent on DHT being integrated.
